name: Sagittarius A*
description: The supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way. It contains about 4 million times the mass of the Sun and shapes the dynamics of our entire galaxy.

name: The Pillars of Creation
description: Iconic structures of gas and dust located in the Eagle Nebula, known for active star formation and captured famously by the Hubble and James Webb telescopes.

name: Messier 87 Black Hole (M87*)
description: The first black hole ever imaged directly. Located in the Virgo Cluster, it is 6.5 billion times the mass of the Sun and emits powerful relativistic jets.

name: The Bo√∂tes Void
description: A gigantic cosmic void roughly 330 million light-years across with extremely few galaxies, often referred to as the 'Great Nothing.'

name: The Andromeda Galaxy
description: The closest major galaxy to the Milky Way and on a collision course with us in about 4.5 billion years. It is larger than the Milky Way and contains a trillion stars.

name: The Carina Nebula
description: A massive stellar nursery home to some of the most massive stars known, including Eta Carinae, a volatile star system that may go supernova soon.

name: The Bullet Cluster
description: A pair of galaxy clusters that collided at high speed. It provides some of the strongest evidence for dark matter due to gravitational lensing effects.

name: GN-z11
description: One of the most distant and oldest galaxies ever observed, formed only 400 million years after the Big Bang. It offers a window into the early universe.
